item.description:
Buriiri is an arrangement type board game where all the players cooperate and fill with the character [hiragana] to which 5 × 5 squares are distributed [hiragana]
The player first decides the number, the first person freely places one letter
The game master randomly distributes two letters to the player who is turning the turn
The active player selects one of the two characters and fills it in the square

Filling conditions
1, it is in contact with the character already existing in the square
2, it is established as a word of two letters together with the character in contact
3, It is possible to explain the meaning of the word to the game master
If conditions are met, you can fill in that square
Repeat as you decided this, if you can fill all the trouts is victory
Unusable vocabulary
Proper noun including place name, family name, character name, etc.
Foreign languages and dialects
There is an item of reading aloud and kun reading in the meaning of the dictionary

Description from the publisher:

Kingmaker: The Reluctant Coronation is a turn-based, tile drafting, anti-set collection game where the goal is NOT to become king, but to instead be responsible for forcing another player to the throne. Being the leader of this cantankerous village is difficult work, best left to someone else. Still, the time has come for a new monarch to be crowned and as the wisest elders still around, one of you will surely become the new person in charge/scapegoat to blame for all the kingdom's problems. To decide who will ascend to this awesome responsibility, you'll present the accoutrements of power to your opponents hoping to ensnare one of them (ANY OF THEM!) with all five: the ring, the robe, the sceptre, the crown and the throne. Be careful! Each item given to another player also gives them a powerful advantage in a future turn. If they survive the round, revenge will come swift and hard.

Every round, each player presents one gift of power to another and then in turn, each player can assert the powers granted by their previously acquired artifacts. These powers can refuse gifts, trade them, introduce new ones or shuffle them around. When a player is bestowed the fifth item in the set and is unable to avoid accepting it, they become king and the player who gave them that item becomes the kingmaker and wins the game.

Never has such a simple journey been so unexpected!

Your penguin must leave the colony to feed on the ocean, then return to his own. Your instinct will guide you to choose the right path, avoid the blizzard and enjoy the help of others.
Memory and tactics will be essential to win this race!

On your turn you choose a card near your penguin to move it on, turning this card. A color appears and if it corresponds to the color of your penguin, you can move again. If not, your moving is over.
After that, you move a white or black chip to a closed card.
When a penguin comes on a card with a white chip, he can play again now, but when he goes on a black chip, he must stop its moving.
A card whithout penguin on it is face off.

When a penguin is on a card of its color, with other penguins, he must bring them with him!

In this game you travel between the different municipalities in Southern Finland by rolling dice. You cruise around the municipalities and do tasks which are given to you by cards. Tasks may include, for example, moving to a certain town on the map. The first one to visit all the four municipalities wins the game.

The Earth is about to be destroyed, but humanity has managed to build enough spaceships to transport part of the population to Mars. Only those lucky few who have a ticket will get aboard.

In Ticket to Mars, each player forms a part of a mega-corporation with different interests, and the player who manages to fulfill more aims will win their own ticket off Earth. During the game, you have to play order cards to rise, to go down, or to move people between spaceships. Each time you want to return your order cards to hand. the countdown advances and ships takes off when the countdown reaches zero. You win victory points depending on how well you've met your secret goals.

Metal Mania is a thematic game that honors the greatest heavy metal bands, with you trying to drive your metal band to the top by recordings demos and LPs, performing in concerts and tours, and drinking beer. Up the irons!

While playing on the meadow or at the sea, making a picknick or working in the garden? But only if you look carefully at the pictures you'll recognize all the details to be able to identify the correct tiles for your board.

Ravensburger children's game. Among 32 different tiles those have to be found which are matching the details on your cardboard.

The rule booklet offers four different variants of playing the games to provide challenges for children from 3 to 6.

item.description:
In the Ivory kingdom, an old portal has been activated due to the abuse of magic. Ancient creatures threaten to destroy the kingdom, but warriors of all Ivory's places come to the call of the king to try to recover the peace.

Mythsgate is an asymmetric game in which a player controls the creatures laying waste to the kingdom while everyone else tries to stop the carnage. During the game, the warriors have to improve their equipment and increase their power reserve to be able to defeat the ancient creatures and close the portal.

item.description:
Spider Pete's Treasure is a children's skill and action game for two to four players. You've caught Spider Pete burying his hoard of ill-gotten goods and it's up to you to steal his treasure using your spinning mechanical hook before he jumps at you. The first player to steal five rings wins the game.

One player controls Spider Pete and the other player acts as the pirate thief. The thief begins by rolling the treasure die to find out how many rings he must steal this turn. He then winds up the mechanical hook and shouts go and begins trying to fish out the appropriate number of rings from the plastic tray. The other player immediately begins rolling and re-rolling the spider dice, hoping to get two spider icons to show. If the thief steals the correct number of rings first, the round is over and he keeps the rings. If the Spider Pete player rolls two spider icons first, he slaps the lever on the back of the box to cause Spider Pete to leap out! If this happens, the thief player must return any rings he stole this turn to the tray. Players take turns being the thief and Spider Pete until someone manages to collect 5 rings and win the game.

item.description:
KaleidoCards is a game system. It consists of a deck of 100 unique coloured cards which are used to play many varied abstract games which are quick to learn and play.

The cards use five 'colours’: Red, Blue, Green, Black and White. Each card has three ‘aspects’: Word, Background and Font Colour. The Word is the name of one of the five colours, the Background of the card is one of the colours, and Font that the word is written in is also one of the colours.

KaleidoCards comes with rules for 7 different games:
• KaleidoClash - a fast-paced game of frantically grabbing cards; 2-8 players; 2-3 minutes.
• KaleidoLine - a turn-based game where players play tactically to get rid of all their cards; 2-8 players; 5-10 minutes.
• KaleidoCall - a quick colour perception game where players call out which colour appears most among multiple cards; 2-8 players; 10-15 minutes.
• KaleidoSeek - a thought-provoking deduction game; 2-8 players; 5-15 minutes.
• KaleidoCombo - a mind-bending perception game where players look for pairs of cards which make a 'combo' of all five colours; 2-8 players; 10-15 minutes.
• KaleidoGrid - a cooperative or solitaire puzzle game of placing cards strategically to score points; 1 or more players; 5-10 minutes.
• KaleidoSpeed - a colour perception speed challenge influenced by the pyschological 'Stroop Test'; 1 or more players; 1 minute/player.

There are many other KaleidoGames which can be played with KaleidoCards, making it a very versatile game system.

KaleidoCards is due to be launched via Kickstarter in summer 2017 soon after being exhibited at UK Games Expo.
Place the Loggerheads on the game board, let the others memorize the order and make a switch. Who can see what has changed? The player with the most tokens at the end wins the game.

Description from the publisher:

Objectives: Vietnam is a cooperative, competative card game for one to six people where players compete against the game to take objectives by battling the NVA forces.

The cards

Objectives: Vietnam runs with three decks of cards. The first deck is the Objectives deck. These cards are places and events that the players must collect before they accumulate in the “War Weariness” pool. Objectives are guarded by a number of NVA cards as designated by the NVA score on the Objective card. Each Objective card also has a Value. This is the number of points the players receive when they take the objective. NVA cards are the second deck and represent the North Vietnam Army. These cards come in different strengths and have varying abilities. The last deck is the Free World deck. These cards are dealt to the players face down and represent the resources they have to take objectives and affect the War Weariness pool. Players may not share or expose their hands to other players during the course of the game.

Setup

Shuffle each deck separately and then deal out a number of Free World cards face down to each player as determined by figure 1 (Number of players). Play starts with the player to the left of the dealer and moves clockwise around the table.

Sequence of play

When a players turn starts they draw one Free World card. If the player has less than their starting hand in Free World cards they draw up to their starting card total instead. Once the player has drawn their cards, the top Objectives card is turned over and placed in the middle of the playing field. This is mandatory and will always happen each players turn. This is the War Weariness pool. The player now has the option of attempting to take the objective (see combat) or take an additional Free World card and pass his turn to the player to his left. If you do nothing in your turn you can always draw one Free World card and this can bring your total cards above your starting hand size. There is no upper limit on the number of cards you can have in your hand.

Combat

When a player decides they are going to take an objective they deal out a number of NVA cards equal to the NVA score on the Objective card face down. Starting with the attacking player, each player “bids” the cards they will use in the attack by placing them face down in front of themselves. Once all players have bid their cards, the player cards are revealed and then the first NVA card in line is revealed. Add up the strength value of all exposed NVA cards each reveal phase and compare it to the total of the Free World card strength. If the NVA total is double the total strength of all the exposed Free World bid cards, the objective is overrun and lost (See losing combat). If the total is not double the attackers strength and there are more NVA cards to be revealed, the players go around again bidding more cards for the next reveal phase. This continues until all NVA cards involved in the battle are face up. If the attacking players have a higher total Strength than the strength total of all NVA cards in play then they win the objective and it is placed to the side. If there are four or more players, the attacking player now draws a number of Free World cards equal to the NVA value on the Objective that was just secured and can now give them to the other players as reinforcements. The player may only keep one card for himself and he may not look at any of the cards being distributed. This may take the player over his starting hand limit. He may then attempt to take another objective or end his turn. If an attack is declared and the players feel they can’t take the objective they can call off the attack but the player that called the attack must discard his entire hand and his turn ends. The objective is treated as if the players lost combat.

Losing combat

Should the players be defeated by the NVA, the objective is placed back in the War Weariness pool and a token is placed on the card. Objectives that have tokens on them add one to the NVA value for each token on the card. This is cumulative with any other effect in the game

War weariness

As the game progresses, cards will begin to build up in the War Weariness pool. The more cards in the War Weariness pool the more difficult it will be to take objectives. Starting with the third card in the War Weariness pool, add one to the NVA score for every Objective card. Once you have six cards in the War Weariness pool you add one more and finally when there is nine cards in the War Weariness pool you add one more for a total of +3 to the NVA score on all Objective cards. If a duplicate Objective card is added to the War Weariness pool it is shuffled back in to the deck and a token is added to the original card in the War Weariness pool instead.

Ending the game

If there are 10 cards in the War Weariness pool at the end of any players turn the game wins. The players win if they accumulate a total of ten points per player, 15 in a single player game. (IE a 4 player game needs to get 40 points in Objectives). The player that initiates the attack keeps the points of the objective if the players win the objective. The player with the most points when the players win is deemed the winner of the game. Note that if the game wins, no one wins.

Using the same chassis as W1815 this game covers the battle of Blenheim 1704.

The game seeks to demonstrate the importance to the Franco-Bavarians of holding the line of villages so as to outflank Allied attacks between them. The Allies must therefore risk attacking these strongly held outposts to clear their main attacks. The villages also give the opportunity to the Franco-Bavarians to use counter-attacks. The French army is no longer the superb weapon of Condé, Turenne or Luxembourg: a force hurling itself forward in a furia franchese. It cannot out face the Allies in the open, but by carefully using counter-attacks it can yet confound the Allies.

The Allies need to balance their attacks along the line to keep the Franco-Bavarians pinned and prevent them moving reserves into areas subject to the main Allied attack. Forces are divided into foot and horse, and these two arms will support each other in combat. Problems arise where foot and horse are not both available. Then infantry can find themselves pinned and shelled, and cavalry unable to attack effectively.

Description from the designer:

Zombie Apocalypse – The Dice Game is a solitaire dice placement game where you control [4] elite Navy SEALs trying to get home by searching for [5] SATCOM electronic communication pieces, through sixteen possible locations containing a variety of hostile combatants: zombies “slow, fast, mutant and radiated”, plus dangerous Raiders. Each of the sixteen locations is randomly generated to create a PATH that must be followed to reach each building and secure each location. Within five of these locations is one piece of the five necessary electronics components that you must retrieve and install into your portable communication device. This communication device must eventually hook up to the control panel at the final location: SATCOM #1. Each of the sixteen locations may also provide critical supplies and equipment to help you along your mission. Be careful, within each location you will find yourself constantly being attacked by hordes of zombies and murderous raiders that will kill you on site!

Five years after the events of Cavern Tavern, where a fragile peace was brokered between The Five Realms, the High Queen Tabita Orestes has ordered a new city to be built. The city of Caveborn will be the capital of the Five Realms, a place where all the races will learn to live together in harmony, with the main purpose being to bring them closer and prevent another war.

The Queen needs to keep the alliance between the races and ensure that Caveborn is peaceful and prosperous. To that end, a Settlers Council has been formed with Berk the Town Clerk as its chairman — but Berk is getting old and needs a successor. Are you that person?

Rise to Nobility is a worker (dice) placement game set in the same fantasy world as Cavern Tavern. You each own a small piece of land in the newly built city, and your job is to rise from anonymity, make your way to the title of lord, and take over the head seat at the Stone Council.

You can achieve this by upgrading your land and increasing its value, satisfying the demands of the settlers' council, attracting and housing as many settlers as you can, accommodating their needs, finding them jobs, and helping them develop from apprentices to guild masters, thus insuring you have people in high places all around the city of Caveborn.

item.description:
Description from the publisher:'

The original MindTrap game was first published 20 years ago. Packed with puzzles, mysteries, brainteasers, conundrums, and trick questions, MindTrap became an international success, selling over 3 million copies worldwide.

For this limited 20th Anniversary edition, we have taken the best questions from MindTrap and MindTrap II, added two new categories, and loads and loads of new content!

Full of quirky characters, baffling brainteasers, and convoluted logic, MindTrap can be played wherever and whenever you want to exercise your brain. MindTrap is the game that challenges the way you think!

Mad Match combines strategy, memory, and cut-throat game play in a fun and exciting new card matching game.

Like in classic Memory, players try to collect pairs (and triplets) of cards to score points. Action cards will cause cards in play to be frozen face up for the rest of the game or allow players to remove or steal cards from opponents.

The basic set includes 54 cards with hilarious and quirky art right out of the Mad Science The Card Game Universe and is perfect for two players. Pull a few cards out of the deck and you can play a classic matching game with children of all ages, or get addicted to our unique Mad Match solitaire variation.

A party game for literate degenerates. Mash up epic quotes!

EndQuotes lets you mash up hundreds of unforgettable lines from movies, tv, songs, books, and more! It consists of two decks of cards: one with quotes with their endings missing, and one with those endings. Each round, the active player draws a quote card, then the other players each secretly choose an ending card in their hand to end that quote with and plays it face-down on the table. The active player then reveals these cards and chooses the ending card that, in his opinion, is the best ending for the quote. The winning player gets the quote card.

Once a player has won a pre-determined number of quote cards, that player wins.

Across all of space and time, the Tricksters play their game. Only a cunning few are privy to the mischief that they wreak. At long last, these champions have gathered from across the multiverse with a sole purpose: put an end to these blasted troublemakers!

Trickster is trick-taking game of multidimensional mischief like no other. Featuring a colorful cast of characters, each with unique abilities, no two games will ever be the same! Only the wiliest Trickster will elude the others and live to trick another day!

name.value: Pocket Escape Room: De tijd vliegt

item.description:
Deckscape: Test Time is the first title in a series of cooperative games inspired by real escape rooms in which a group of people are "trapped" inside a room full of puzzles and odd items. The goal of the game is to solve puzzles, understand the plot of the story, and make intelligent use of the items provided in order to exit from the room as quickly as possible.

In Deckscape: Test Time, you have been selected from Doctor Thyme's most brilliant students for a special project. He'll test your skills, and if you succeed, you'll get a unique chance to help him on his newest and greatest invention. While he's explaining his project, he distractedly pushes a button: an alarm cries loudly and heavy gratings shut all the windows and the exit door. The laboratory is locked! Doc Thyme falls through a trapdoor below his feet and the lights turn off. Will you be able to pass Doctor Thyme's exam and exit his laboratory? Using just sixty cards, you will take part in a hectic adventure, without leaving home.

—description from the publisher

item.description:
Description from the publisher:

In Stoplight, 2 to 6 players race to outwit the stoplights and get out of town the fastest.

On a turn, one player rolls all three plush dice, which are different colors and sizes. All players must race to place a hand on the proper die based to the numbers rolled: the red die if it shows the highest number, the green die if it shows the lowest number, and the yellow die if it shows a number between the numbers on the other two dice. If there are no dice on which to place your hand, raise both your hands and yell "Stop!"

item.description:
In the cooperative game 3 Secrets, players want to unravel the three secrets of an unresolved case before time runs out. One of the players plays the role of informant and knows the truth about the case: They know which secrets need to be discovered and try their best to help you guess them correctly. The clock is ticking and the clues are scarce, so question the informant to gather useful information and find the solution. If you grope in the dark, the informant can reveal an important clue, but this will cost you precious time! Use your best observing eye, lateral thinking, and deduction skills to unravel all the mysteries of the ambiguous characters that populate this game.

3 Secrets comes with a free app available for download at the Apple AppStore and Google Play.

item.description:
Each player has to get 4 meeples from the starting space to the 4 destination spaces of his color. 2 meeples use the left side and 2 meeples use the right side of the game board. Movement is determined by rolling a die.

If a meeple gets on a free green space, the Player shouts: "Mensch, sei kein Frosch!" and takes the next opponent meeple in front of him back to the starting space. If the green space is already occupied, the player sets his meeple on the space in front of it and pays a token into the cash box.

Whenever a meeple gets on a free red space, it changes places with the next opponent meeple in front of it. If the red space is occupied, the player sets his meeple two spaces in front of it and pays a token into the cash box.

If a meeple gets on space 80/81 the player has to miss a turn. If the space is alredy occupied, the first meeple is moved 6 free black spaces backwards.

Space 100 must be reached by exact count. Only meeples that are standing on space 100 may move onto the destination spaces. If the player rolls too many points, the surplus points must be moved backwards.

The first player to get his 4 meeples to his 4 destination spaces wins the game and two thirds of the cash box.

Gangs of Commorragh allows you to recreate the violent skirmish battles for territorial supremacy that are waged constantly in the spires of the Dark City. Take charge of a feral gang of Hellion skyboarders or a pack of lethal Reavers, then carve out your empire in the webway's last great city.

The box is a self-contained game, giving you everything you need to play, including two gangs, rules and card scenery to recreate the jagged towers of Commorragh's forbidding skyline.

You can play quick one-off games, or a full campaign in which your gang will grow and develop as you win battles and claim more territory.

item.description:
Description from the publisher:

Introduction

Learningames offers a new and exciting way to have fun while learning geography. Through these innovative and easy-to-play games players master important information about the political and physical geography of the world. A valuable experience for young and old, novice or expert. Learningames are unique, informative, and always enjoyable.

Overview of play

Two to six players sit around the Map Playing Board. The map may include political centers and/or geographical areas. In place of the names of the political centers (including cities, states, and nations) and geographical areas (including physical features, regions, and cultural and economic centers) normally found on the map are numbers 1-50.
To begin the game a player draws a Card form the deck. Each card has the name of a political center or geographical area on one side (Side “A” with the blue background) and a number with important information about the named center or area on the other side (Side “B” with the white background).
In the Basic Game players win cards by locating and naming different political centers or a geographical area on the numbered playing board or by correctly challenging incorrect answers. When playing the Advanced Games, players master important information about the political centers and geographical areas identified in the basic games. Players always find Learningames fun, and best of all, they learn about the world around them.

Description from the publisher:

Introduction

Learningames offers a new and exciting way to have fun while learning geography. Through these innovative and easy-to-play games players master important information about the political and physical geography of the world. A valuable experience for young and old, novice or expert. Learningames are unique, informative, and always enjoyable.

Overview of play

Two to six players sit around the Map Playing Board. The map may include political centers and/or geographical areas. In place of the names of the political centers (including cities, states, and nations) and geographical areas (including physical features, regions, and cultural and economic centers) normally found on the map are numbers 1-50.
To begin the game a player draws a Card form the deck. Each card has the name of a political center or geographical area on one side (Side “A” with the blue background) and a number with important information about the named center or area on the other side (Side “B” with the white background).
In the Basic Game players win cards by locating and naming different political centers or a geographical area on the numbered playing board or by correctly challenging incorrect answers. When playing the Advanced Games, players master important information about the political centers and geographical areas identified in the basic games. name.value: Mobile Suit Gundam Wing: Obiettivo Terra

item.description:
User summary:

The Oz Army is controlling the Earth, and is your objective to be the first to destroy them.

In Mobile Suit Gundam Wing - Obiettivo Terra you, and the other players, will play as one of the 5 main characters from A New translation: Mobile suit Gundam W.

Each different pilot is suited with is iconic Mobile Suit, which differ not only in design, but in performance too.

For example, Duo Maxwell pilots the Gundam Deathscythe, which is a really fast machine, while Trowa Barton prefer the Gundam Heavyarms, perfect for suppressive fire tactics.

The game is played on a pre-print board, divided in squares.

On the board (which represent a stylized version of the Lagrangian points around the Earth) there are indicated each player's starting point, which represent 4 different Colony, some Asteroids to mine for gathering resources, and the Earth, with is defensive line.

The objective of the game is to be the first to defeat the Gundam Epyon, the mobile suit piloted by the unknown leader of the Oz Army, waiting on the Earth (the center of the board) for a worthy opponent.
Each player’s turn starts by throwing 2 dice: this indicates the numbers of squares you may move on the board.

At the end of the "Movement Phase", you must draw an "Event Card", unless you end your movement on an Asteroid or a Colony: in the first case, you may mine it to draw a "Resource Card", in the latest you may un-load your Mobile Suit in the Colony's hangar bay.

Each “Event Card” may trigger different effect, it could make you challenge some Mobile Suit from the Oz Army, sent to defeat you.
Each time you encounter an enemy Mobile Suit (or you land on the same spot of another player) a battle occur: you throw 2 dice and, by using the "Battle Table", match a particular stat of you Suit with the enemy's one.

Some “Event Cards” will let you boost the performance of your Mobile Suit, or let you avoid the encounter immediately, or give you some other kind of bonus or malus.
Before jumping ahead to the main villain, you will first have to clear 2 missions:

 gather enough resources to build the Gundam Wing Zero (even if you like it, your first Mobile Suit will never be able to defeat the Gundam Epyon)
 meet the requirements on a random "Diplomacy card" drawn at the beginning of the game;




once you are done, you can go and try to defeat the "bad guy”, finally freeing Earth from the Oz Army oppression!

Description from the publisher:
L’obiettivo del gioco è raccogliere materiali dalle colonie con il vostro Gundam per costruire il potentissimo Gundam Wing Zero.
L’operazione non sarà semplice perché ad ostacolarvi ci saranno orde dei temibili mobile suit di OZ e ovviamente gli altri giocatori. Una volta costruito il GWZ sarete in grado di tornare sulla Terra ed affrontare lo spaventoso Gundam Epyon per l’epico scontro finale

item.description: The family-friendly game Cards Against Profanity takes the popular adult party game and gives you a fun and wholesome experience that even your kids and their friends can enjoy. Designed for ages 8+, Cards Against Profanity has 75 quirky question cards and 425 funny answer cards. Each round, the "ruler" deals the players eight white answer cards, then flips over one orange question card. Players then place one of their white cards face-down. The ruler then selects the best answer!

Rhino Hero is back on the job — and this time not only does the wobbly skyscraper need to be climbed, but there will also be fierce battles between the four super-heroes Rhino Hero, Giraffe Boy, Big E. and Batguin. Who will win the battles and not let themselves be bothered by the mean, hanging spider monkeys?

Rhino Hero: Super Battle is a turbulent 3D stacking game.

item.description:
This is a very unusual Japanese travel game published by the Osaka Mainichi newspaper in 1926 (Taisho 15), quite unlike the typical Mawari-Sugoroku board, which has a path of pictures spiralling toward the center.

This game is a huge map of the world surrounded by flags. It measures about 43" tall and 30" wide. It is oriented (no pun intended) toward the East at the top, with North to the left, South to the right and West downwards. Japan is centered in the upper half, with the Pacific and Americas above it, Australia to the right, Asia/India in the middle and Europe/Africa at the bottom.

The map shows a wide variety of destinations linked by numbered routes. Each player starts from Japan and travels in the direction indicated by a die roll (with a 6 going nowhere). The objective is to reach London by travelling either east or west, with North America at the top connecting to European/African destinations at the bottom.

The period illustrations are wonderful, including a bust of Lenin in Leningrad (with a train heading back to Germany), Charlie Chaplin being filmed as the little tramp in Hollywood, a cannibal eating a white man in Indonesia, a hookah-smoking Turk, a kilted Scot, an arrogant European waiter, a Dutch girl in clogs and a Spaniard fighting a bull. There also are drawings of all the famous sights, from Niagara Falls, the Taj Mahal and the Pyramids to the Kremlin, Statue of Liberty, Westminster, and a biplane flying over the Eiffel Tower.

Fortresses & Clans is a two-player card game in which each player is a clan leader who oversees their troops and warmachines with the help of their clan members in order to destroy the opponent's fortress.

You'll have to draft your army cards with your opponent, place them on the good spots on your own fortress, and then activate them by using your clan cards wisely.

name.value: Harry Potter: Magical Beasts Board Game

item.description:
Set in the Harry Potter world, you play as one of the four characters, Harry Potter, Ron Weasley, Hermione Granger or Ginny Weasley in a race to discover the magical beasts. You will collect clues to track down creatures inside and outside Hogwarts.

The objective is to obtain four cards that corresponds to one beast. Each turn, a player will roll the dice which will correspond to the number of spaces a player moves. When a player lands on a tile that indicates a type of a card (Color, Size, Location or M.O.M Classification), they get to take one card from that pile. The card is then placed facedown. Should you obtain another card of that type, you place the new card on top of the other card. The dice ranges from 2-6 with one of the sides showing a "P". When this side is rolled, the player who rolled it, gets to go to a passage (location space marked with a "P") of his/her choice. All other players not on a "P" are temporarily removed. The game board then shifts and the player who rolled the "P" are able to put the other players on any tile of his/her choosing and can steal one of their cards. First player who obtains all four cards of each type for one magical beasts wins.

item.description:
Description from the publisher:

Rampunctious is a party game about making terrible puns and word play. The game starts by the players making puns out of their own names. Whoever has the best pun becomes the Pundit. The Pundit has a hand of 5 Topic cards, they draw a Scenario card from the deck and read it aloud to start the round. Each Scenario shows a unique fictitious situation. The Pundit then plays a Topic of their choice from their hand and the players must make as many puns as possible by combining. At the end of a round the Pundit awards the Scenario card as a point to whoever made the best, worst or most puns. The game ends when a player reaches 10 points. 
At any point in a game, if a player makes a pun that causes everyone to cringe they can be awarded a Cringe card as a reward. Depending on how you're playing these may count as a point.

item.description: Artem is a game of risk taking, careful strategy and a board that's constantly changing. Every turn players take turns either manipulating the position of color tiles or claiming a row of colors. In order to claim a row, you just need a claim card of the same color.

This game is from January 2017's 24-Hour Contest!

The premise is simple: You and a group of your friends stink at keeping New Year's Resolutions. You all decide to pitch in $1,000 to see who's the most dedicated to their resolution. The most dedicated player wins(dedicated= most progress made on their respective board)!

Game play: the majority of the game is spent trying to manipulate the decisions of your opponents, by playing cards to improve yourself and sabotage others!

Overkill is a card game where you compete to come up with the most ridiculous or creative horror movie-themed kill. Players take on the roles of various monsters from horror movie lore, and compete for the most prized victims – when the sun rises, the player with the most total point’s worth of victims wins!

Create a stack of six "victim cards" and compete to kill the top victim card in each of the six rounds by creating a gruesome tale with your murder cards explaining what you intend to do to said victim. Story cards numbered 1 to 6 that describe just how you intend to pummel them to death and with what, where, your ritual, when you'll stop the pummeling, and why you finally decide they're dead. But as you weave your tale other players might add on to you story with frustrating "But" cards that nullify part of your plan. Every time you play a card, you must read the entire story aloud which is really where this game shines, however other than a good laugh, the story you weave is irreverent for the victory, as the player with the most cards (1 thru 6, only one of each number may be in play per player) claims the victim. Different victims have different points, and and the end victim points are added up to see who wins the game.

Look it's a cheerleader, I'm going to skin her, with a chainsaw, in a creepy motel, while laughing maniacally, until the prophecy is complete, because she knows too much. But..... you won't be using that chainsaw because she knows your secret weakness!

It’s game on for minion-against-minion action in the Minions Challenge Card Game! Each one of these hilarious Minion characters comes with 5 cards and a game guide. Deploy your battle cards against your opponent and keep playing until your Minion reaches the top of his score card first to win! (Source: Publisher Website)

Gameplay Overview:

32 Unique Card Decks are available. Each contains 5 Cards and one Minion Figure.


 Players combine 3 Unique Card Decks to form their draw deck. 
 Players draw 4 cards to form hand
 Play cards from hand simultaneously, apply any affects
 If one minion defeats the other, move that minion up one space in score track. Repeat, re-draw after every 4 cards played, shuffling as necessary.
 Once all Minions (or the number of agreed upon minions) on one team have reached the end of their score tracks, that player wins the game

item.description:
Direwild is a fully co-operative, tactical, dungeon-crawling deck-builder. There is no dungeon master; it is purely the players vs. the game. Players assume the role of animists, heroes that can summon creatures both great and small (represented in the cards you build your deck with), then combine those creatures in unique ways. With the creatures' help, the animists strive to work as a team to defeat the evil forces of Karn. Karn was once a great animist himself, but was corrupted by his lust for greater power. Throughout the game, Karn tries to hunt the heroes and defeat them before they can grow strong enough to face him in the final showdown. The game is split into three chapters, with a "game save" mechanism to allow for the packing and saving of the game between game nights.

The game also includes treasure, magic, unlockable upgrades, boss fights, a large pool of minions to randomly face each playthrough, over 130 creatures, and ten unique heroes!

item.description:
An educational game where children learn the letters of alphabet with familiar Moomin characters. There are seven difficulty levels which can be adjusted to match the skills of children. Contains letter tiles, player boards, dice, and game rules.

This is basically a memory game. On your turn you flip a tile, check whether it fits on your player board, then either collect cover a letter on your player board or flip the tile back. First player to cover all letters on their player board is the winner.

Easiest level is just finding matching letter pairs. More advanced variants include matching lowercase letters to uppercase letters, or matching a picture to starting letter of the picture.

Swordpoint is a “big battle” miniature wargame for fighting actions in the ancient and medieval periods. It employs multi-figure bases, various sizes of figures can be used. Games fought with Swordpoint involve between 100 and 250 miniature figures per side arranged into between 6 and 12 units. The game is designed to play out in about 2 hours after set-up, and gives a large battle feel. Swordpoint encourages the use of historical tactics and emphasises the need to maintain cohesion in the army’s battle line, without being prescriptive. Swordpoint is divided into four game phases per turn. Morale Phase, Shooting Phase, Movement Phase and Combat Phase. Combat results are decided by dice rolls with added modifiers, such as unit special rules and terrain.

Description from the publisher:

Sine Tempore is a cooperative game in which 1 - 4 players face the game’s artificial intelligence as part of a campaign, which guides them to one of three different endings.

Sine Tempore is a game rich in high-detailed miniatures that plunge players into the planet’s alien atmosphere, guided by spectacular scenarios.

Each mission has an objective that needs to be successfully reached to determine whether or not a territory has been conquered, and whether or not new sectors can still be explored.

During the end game phase, each conquered sector will provide colonists with access to the resources they need to build new structures and equipment.

The final mission taken on by players will radically change their destiny.

Sine Tempore will take you back to a faraway past, thousands of years before Nova Aetas, exploring new worlds in search of a new home where characters can live and prosper.

During this long journey, your spaceship will come across a number of different alien species, some friendly, others somewhat suspicious or openly hostile.

In the box you’ll find 39 miniatures, 4 of which are heroes, with whom you will delve into the dangers of Primevus V, through unexplored jungles, used as hunting grounds by Primaevi and the ancient ruins of civilisation used by the latter as a resting base.
A campaign designed to be replayed with different paths each time will lead you to 3 different endings in your search for the resources you need to survive.

An efficient “end game” system will help you to develop your characters through a modern tree skill system and a tested crafting mechanism inspired by Nova Aetas.

item.description:
The year is 1920. Beneath the surface of society, an ancient and enigmatic Church suppresses knowledge of the supernatural to protect the greater good of humanity and retain its grip on the world. Vast conspiracies with unknown ends move in the shadows — secret societies and ancient empires — and they seek to restore the lost, mystical power of ages past. Dark magic breeds monsters within the hearts of men, which break through to the surface and consume them. It falls to the hunters of the Church to destroy these monsters before they come to light.

Take on the role of a Church Hunter, a sworn defender of the world against the forces of darkness, in Seventh Cross and delve into the heart of evil as you explore your way through ever-changing castles filled with unique narrative. Meet mysterious and treacherous characters, do battle with terrible monsters, and confront the darkness in your own soul as you walk the narrow line between the pursuit of power and its ultimate cost.

Seventh Cross is a rogue-like exploration game for 2-6 players that combines elements of paragraph adventure games like Tales of the Arabian Nights and exploration elements like Betrayal at House on the Hill together to form a Castlevania/Bloodborne/Helsing sort of narrative adventure.

item.description:
Game about World Youth Day consists of 64 cards - illustration depicting the young pilgrims in scenes typical of the events of World Youth Day: among others, adoration, during a concert or gathered around the Pope's moving in the popemobile.
The task of the players is to direct the movement of pilgrims to be combined in appropriate groups, according to the dynamically changing criteria. The gameplay counts perceptiveness and speed. The game is developed in a way that does not require verbal communication between players. So they can play it by people of different languages.

Both sides of the cards are important. One of them is showing the scene with the pilgrims, the other one of the 16 features which are showed on the cards. Player one by one take card from the pile and lay out near the card pile. The top card on the pile shows what features on the cards the player are looking for. For example if the card on the card pile shows red clothes players are checking is there at least three cards with this features. If yes whoever will be the first to notice this and put his hand on the pile is the winner of the round. He will take two cards as a reward. After that next person lay out the next cards from the card pile. So feature which players have to looking for is changing continually.

The winner is the person which have the most cards at the end of the game.

This is a family educational game designed for 2-4 people from the age of 8 years of age It consists in incarnating the role of a tourist who visits the 10 municipalities belonging to the Local Action Group "Between the Vistula and Kampinos." Along the way, players visit, among others, nature reserves, monuments, more or less known places, earning points and knowledgeable about the area. While wandering tourists should avoid encounters with moose and try not to disturb other visitors in exploring the beautiful countryside. The game has three difficulty options, so that pleases both the younger and older players.

On his turn player have to choose one of three actions.

 First action "Gathering information" is the move and taking the one card. First move to the neighboring region is for free. For the next player have to pay in "footer". To each region one card is assignment. Card which is taken have to be hold in hands. 
 Second possible actions "Sightseeing" allow player to move and play cards from the hand on the table. The cards on the table will score the points at the end of the game. During this action only card from from the region where player end the move can be played. 
 The third action "Rest" allow player to simply take three "footer". 




The cards score in five categories. The more cards you have in each categories the more point you have.

This rare game is one of only two published by Hamilton-Meyers Co. of Middletown, PA around 1890.

The game is a fairly routine roll-and-move affair, with players having to move four pawns from the castle in their corner of the board toward the center. The tracks are separate and colored red, yellow, blue and black, but they do cross over one another, with a picture of various bridges in the spaces where they do.

The artwork is fabulous, featuring medieval knights in battle, castles and heraldry, all in pastel tones, with an elaborate wreath in the middle awaiting the winner.

This 2-player game with an 1893 copyright has a very unusual board. On each side, a rainbow of half-circles reaches most of the way to the fold in the middle. In between is a ragged checkerboard pattern of white and blue squares, with two large red squares overlapping some of the regular ones at the fold, and five orange squares on each side that connect to the outer arc of circles.

Starting at the center, the arcs are colored brown, black, blue, green, yellow, orange and red, two white lines and three rows of white hollow circles run from the middle to the edges. Within the green, yellow, orange and red bands are additional white circles, with the ones in the outer red band having white lines connecting them to the orange squares on the checkerboard.

It is not clear from the board what the rules were, but it was obviously a game of maneuver with circular and radial as well as checkerboard moves.

Gravehold remains the last bastion of The World That Was. As the otherworldly incursions from the creatures known only as The Nameless intensify, a cadre of strange survivors emerge from the void itself. Will they be Gravehold's salvation or its undoing?

War Eternal is a standalone game compatible with the cooperative deck-building game Aeon's End. Players struggle to defend Gravehold from The Nameless and their hordes using unique abilities, powerful spells, and an all-new cast of dynamic characters. Featuring a number of innovative mechanisms, including a variable turn order system that simulates the chaos of an attack and deck management rules that require careful planning, War Eternal can be played alone or combined with other Aeon's End content for a game experience like no other.

Aeon's End: Tabletop Day 2017 Promos – Drown in Flames / Glyph Enigma

item.description:
Stadium is a contest to see who can build the strongest professional football empire!

This is a worker placement game in which the board is a three-tiered stadium. Players must build on the ground level first as they sell concessions at games, buy equipment for the team, draft all pro players, and do their best to have a winning season. Players also hire employees who can inspire fans, sell more merchandise, train team members, and make building deals as they watch their franchise rise to the sky.

Players carefully choose business decisions, watch salaries and signing bonuses, and replace broken equipment and the occasional injured player. They gain bonuses if they choose the right actions and may end up paying extra if they are not first to build new amenities to their stadium.

Description from the publisher:

Mike & Joe’s Card Game is a fast-paced challenge for 2-6 players that combines THREE GAMES into one madcap session. The object of the game is to be the first player to gather seven cards of the same color, red, green or blue. Cards are accumulated through victories in any of the three games, Patter, Peril or Pointz.

Before each turn, players submit their Player Cards, face-down. Then the current player flips over the top card of the Draw Deck, the House Card, revealing the game for that turn.

If the game is Patter, the current player has but a few seconds, counted down by their opponents, to create a word from the letters on the revealed cards. They win the cards from whatever word they make.

If the game is Peril, the current player pits the Battle Icon on their Player Card against the icon on their opponent's card. If more than one opponent challenges, the player conducts Semifinals until only one challenger remains. The winner receives the Peril Prize, either two or three cards.

If they game is Pointz, the current player uses their finger to move along the board game squares on the bottom of the Player Cards. If they land on a pointing challenge, they have but a few seconds, again counted down by opponents, to point at the indicated item.

The first player to gather seven cards of the same color in their bank wins the game and is held in awe by the other players.

THE GAMEPLAY

Street Masters is a 1-4 player cooperative miniatures board game inspired by classic fighting video games. Featuring over 65 highly detailed miniatures, unique decks for fighters & enemies, custom dice, and lightning-fast gameplay, Street Masters lets players match up powerful fighters against villainous organizations in a wide array of exciting scenarios. Designed by Adam Sadler and Brady Sadler, the game offers modular and elegant gameplay set in a unique and exciting world of brutal combat.

THE STORY

Warriors from around the world, known for their legendary fighting abilities and skills, receive mysterious invitations to participate in a martial arts tournament. During the tournament, the organization surrounding it reveals their true identity — The Kingdom — and their purpose to recruit fighters to join their militia or enslave those against them. While several of these warriors made it out in time, many were never heard from again.

Five years later, a government project called "Street Masters" initiates in order to counter-act the war against The Kingdom, now having divided and seized control over the world by several of its factions. Those who join the Street Masters project must work together to take down each faction, crippling parts of The Kingdom before they're able to launch their end game.

item.description:
Card Castle is a fast-paced, slapping card game that puts your reflexes to the test. Out-slap others to win cards and rule the Card Castle! Inspired by traditional card games like War and Slap-Jack, Card Castle adds several new twists including battling armies, tricky look-alikes, powerful Wizards, and fiery dragons.

In more detail, the goal in Card Castle is to out-slap your opponents, win all their cards, and become ruler of the castle. Players take turns flipping cards blindly from the top of their army decks onto the center of the table or playmat. When slappable opportunities present themselves (doubles, doors, or wizards), the first player to slap the pile of cards wins the battle and all the cards in the pile.

But be sure you don't slap the dragon!

name.value: Cha-Cha Chihuahua: The Game of Dancing Doggies

item.description:
Description from the publisher:

Jump, jive, and wag your tail! Draw cards to get these peppy perritos to join your doggy dance-a-thon in Cha-Cha Chihuahua: The Game of Dancing Doggies.

Paw away another player's pups with some fetching food, but watch out for "siesta" cards that will send your dog-tired dancers straight to the Nap Shack! End the party with the most chihuahuas on your dance floor and you're the cha-cha-champ!

item.description:
Description from the publisher:

Collect and battle to build a massive MolecuRing and destroy your opponent in a strategy game loaded with science facts and learning. Atomicals are at war to build the most massive MolecuRing and gain ultimate valence control! Strategy is the key element in this chemistry battle. Create your attack plan, partner your Chemicals, master your Labs and Energies, and destroy your opponent’s MolecuRing while defending your own!

This card battle game is based on the elements of the periodic table and science facts related to chemistry and physics.
CAUTION! You may accidentally learn about element groups, chemical bonds, oxidation states, chemical reactions, states of matter, energy transfer, scientific theories, and material properties.

Description from the publisher:

You are a wizard's apprentice, thrust into a thrilling quest to find your master who has mysteriously disappeared. Do you venture into an ominous lair, or use some warpdust to teleport to a cliff-side cave? Will you defeat the devious Dark Fairy by conjuring a catapult, or is it better to drink a super-strength potion? Your journey unfolds with every choice in Vanished, a spellbinding Cardventure in which the correct path may just be an illusion!

item.description:
Welcome to the wonderful musical world of PABLO!

Pablo comes with 140 cards with words and categories in Portuguese and English, divided among wild, hard, medium and easy cards.

All players are dealt a hand of cards and can also use the cards open on the table to sing a song using the words they have available.

For every card played matching a word on the song, you get points according to the difficulty of that card. But the real fun is that anyone can jump in and sing a long with you if they have a word in their hands that is also on your song. After singing each player score the cards used.

A wild card can be used as any word that fits its categories and will be worth the number of cards you played that round in points!

Also included are the Microphone Token that will let you exchange cards, the Onomatopoeia Token that will double your points if the song has words like Yeah-Yeah-Yeah, and the Tomato Token that doesn’t has a specific rule to it other than throwing at your opponents play area when they sing a song wrong!

Components:
140 Musical Notes Cards
30 Microphone Tokens
30 Onomatopoeia Tokens
10 Tomato Tokens
30 Golden Disc Tokens
20 Platinum Disc Tokens
20 Diamond Disc Tokens
Rules

Description from the publisher:

You are a legendary time traveler on a mission to collect both ancient artifacts and futuristic gizmos. You've got all the time in the world, so which part of history will you raid first? Do you race chariots in the Roman Empire or outwit Ben Franklin during the American Revolution? Should you face off against a futuristic robot or try to capture a prehistoric dinosaur?

The choice is yours in Time Raiders, a time-twisting Cardventure — just be careful not to alter history too much before you make it back to the present!

name.value: Think 'n Sync: The Great Minds Think Alike Game

item.description:
Description from the publisher:

3… 2… 1… Sync! Meld your minds in Think n' Sync, a party game of quick connections. Pick a partner and then, at the same time, shout out an answer to the chosen category. Can you both name a movie princess? An ice cream flavor? How about something orange? Your answers may be great, but they score only if they're identical! So think quickly, think cleverly, but most importantly think in sync!

The classic card game now in a giant size! Each card measures 7.4 inches x 10.1 inches!

Race to get rid of all your cards and match colors or numbers.
Use the action cards or house rule cards against your opponents. When you're down to one card, don't forget to yell "UNO"!
Play the 'Swap Hands' card to change hands with any opponent.
3 customizable cards let you write any house rule you want and erase to make new rules!

A fast-paced bidding boardgame designed by Balangay Entertainment.

The Big Switch is a real-time bidding and tile-flipping dexterity game about energy conservation. In each round, players try to outbid each other in 20-second auctions to buy efficient appliances for their homes, while simultaneously doing energy saving habits.

Players compete to have the most Energy Stars which they get from buying appliances and doing habits. The player with the most Energy Stars after 7 rounds is the winner!

A family of tourists arrives in London. Their objective: Explore the city and take as many selfies as they can in front of the main monuments. This race to take selfies won't happen smoothly because they'll need to answer the questions correctly — making use of vocabulary, grammar, culture, etc. — to advance and escape the traps laid by other players. Each character will have a special power.

Mission Selfie London makes learning English into a game for young players. Different difficulty levels allow the whole family to play together.

Contrast is a light party game in which players score points by characterizing objects the same way.

Each player has a deck of the same six cards, and each card has either opposite characteristics (short/long, round/square, etc.) or a pair of colors (red/yellow, blue/green). In each round, players simultaneously reveal one of the four cards they have in hand — as the other two cards are in front of them and cannot be used — with that card matching the top picture of the picture card deck in some way. The image might show a red balloon in the sky, for example, so do you reveal red, round, blue, or something else?

Everyone simultaneously reveals their chosen card. If a player has voted with the majority, they take a picture card from the deck to keep track of their points. Then everyone refreshes their hand by picking up their left-most card and putting down their played card on the right. Then, another round begins.

After the picture deck runs out, whoever has the most picture cards wins.

item.description:
Description from the publisher:

Faeries race from opposite ends of the board for the safety of the central line while bombarding each other with cheese. Helpful trolls blunder about, collecting up the cheese to replenish the faeries' cheese stock, but also impede their faerie friends' progress.

The game comprises a leather board (11 x 5.5”) and hand-finished wooden pieces; with plastic dice. Each player has six faeries, one troll and six wedges of cheese. In a turn a player rolls four dice - one pink, one green and two yellow. Using the number rolled on the pink die, the player moves a faerie towards the middle safe line on the board. With the green die the player moves the troll, who can pick up cheese that has been thrown by the opposing player. Using the two numbers rolled on the yellow dice as co-ordinates, the player ‘throws’ cheese into their opponent's half of the board. Any faerie this lands on is eliminated from the game; cheese also blocks the movement of faeries towards the safe line.

Each player aims to move as many of their own faeries as possible to the central line and off the board, while eliminating or blocking the movement of their opponent's faeries by throwing cheese at them. The winner is the player who, once one player has no more faeries to move, has most faeries safe. If the result is tied, numbers of remaining faeries and cheese on the board can determine the winner.

ReFloristation is a new card game designed by Paul Harris and Published by Spiral Galaxy Games.

Run your own successful floristry business in this fun card collection drafting and deck-building game. Collect orders, recruit and manage staff, visit the flower market for supplies, and pack your orders off in your delivery van to earn enough money to beat your rivals’ shops. You can even plant your own nursery to get ahead.

ReFloristation is remarkably strategic and replayable; plotting your resource management, making clever choices to create the best combination of staff, and timing your moves for the best possible advantage make the game exciting and thematic. ReFloristation is suitable for gamers of all ages and abilities, whether you ever dreamed of owning a flower shop or not.

Description from the publisher:

Relive the fun of the arcade Crane Games in this easy to play dice game. You and your friends compete with one another to try and collect the best toys from a field of tokens. Once a player has achieved a set collection value, hidden goals are revealed and the player with the highest valued collection wins. This game features 6 custom dice and over 70 unique toys with illustrations.

Players all move around a central field of 36 toys. Within this field of Toys, several are stacked up on one another. Players have to decide if their dice will be spent on Movement around this grid or Grip, necessary for picking these toys up. Special toys allow the player a chance to push their luck.

Cerebria is a dynamic, team-based, objective-driven area control game, where players play as Spirits, powerful entities representing Bliss or Gloom. These opposing forces - the two sides of human nature - struggle to control and shape the Inside World, the metaphorical representation of an evolving personality.
 Cerebria introduces a unique theme and numerous innovative mechanisms. The game is centered around the player-controlled Spirits, and the Emotion cards controlling Cerebria’s areas, each with their own stats and abilities.

The Spirits can perform up to three actions on their turn. These include moving between Cerebria’s Realms and Frontiers, using the specific powers of the Realms, invoking and upgrading Emotion cards, removing opposing Emotions, and building Fortresses to consolidate their influence on certain areas. The Actions cost Willpower, gained primarily by absorbing from the Origin’s Spheres in the middle of the board. Both Bliss and Gloom also have a rare shared team resource, Ambition, enabling them to use the game’s most powerful effects.
 The teams can score points either by accomplishing publicly known minor objectives (the Intentions), or completing their major objectives (the Aspirations), which change dynamically during the course of the game. Scoring Aspirations allows players to add Bliss and Gloom Fragments to the Identity, built in the middle of the board. These are key moments in the game: Cerebria’s state is in constant flux, but the Fragments are permanent imprints of a game state during the scoring events.
 The game is won by the side with more influence over the finished Identity, thus becoming the dominant force in Cerebria.

link.value: Cerebria: The Inside World – Forces of Balance
Cerebria: The Inside World – Origin Box

item.description:
Description from the designer:

Space Castle! The game of the future! (or is it the past?) It takes just 5 minutes to learn how to play and so much longer to master. Fortify your castle with 16 Warriors before the Alien ships above destroy your kingdom with "Mr. Gotcha Bombs".

You play the game alone for 20 minutes and count how many hands you have won. Afterwards, you can pass the deck to a friend and see if they can beat your score. Who will be the Ultimate Defender of the Space Castle!?

Cards are full color and printed with a spot UV on a thick 14pt stock. Includes 43 card deck, rule book, and carrying pouch.

item.description:
Description from the publisher:

This is Clutch Baseball–an exciting, fast-paced fantasy game. Build a team, craft the perfect strategy deck, and choose a home stadium.

The quest for the perfect deck starts here. Create a team based on a set salary cap, choose strategy cards that will solidify their strengths, and select the stadium that will give you an unbeatable home field advantage.

Every at bat includes two basic elements–the Pitch & Swing. To keep it simple: the Pitch determines who will get the advantage in the at bat, and the Swing determines the result of the at bat.

The game is played and scored just like traditional baseball using player cards that are Batters and Pitchers from real big league teams with suitable stats on a playmat resembling a baseball field. Play a full game (9 innings) consisting of 3 outs per ½ inning, with the Away Manager batting in the top half of the inning. As you send each batter card up to the plate, there is a pitch roll and a swing roll to determine the result (out, walk, hit, home run, etc).

Batter cards move around the bases to score runs like in real baseball. The game ends after 9 innings with the team that scored more runs being the winner - in the event of a tie you go to extra innings until one team comes out ahead!

Strategy cards played at different times give bonuses or allow you to make real baseball plays like hit-and-run, defensive shifts or even a suicide squeeze. You can use pinch hitters and runners, make pitching changes and other real baseball decisions.

name.value: Give and Take: The Game of Soil Building

item.description:
This is a spin-and-move affair published in 1928 by the National Fertilizer Association. The square board is divided into quadrants, each with illustrations and spaces related to a different kind of farm: Dairy Farm, General Farm, Grain Farm and Truck Farm.

The reward and penalty spaces in each quadrant have distinct explanations. In the Dairy Farm, for instance, C = "Turned cattle in pasture too early in spring. Lose 1 Spin, while on the Truck Farm this space reads "Soil very acid; limed adequately. Go Ahead 1, Take 1 Spin."

There is a separate booklet that provides more detailed information about the good and bad practices flagged on the board.

The 16"-square board itself is lavishly illustrated, although on plain beige cardboard, with images related to each kind of farm. The game was distributed in a plain brown envelope.

Description from the publisher:

Gorizia 1916, La sesta battaglia dell'Isonzo (the Isonzo sixth battle), is a low-medium complexity tactical game on the campaign conducted by the Italian forces against Austria, during August 1916.

This is a mini-monster, very playable game with many hundreds die-cut counters, one 22"x34" map with large hexes representing the theater of the Isonzo River, at a scale of 900m per hex, 1 day per game-turn. Each unit counter represents a battalion, or an artillery battery.

The game system is the same as its predecessor, Strafexpedition 1916ï»¿
